title: Day 63 – Salida, CO to Sargents, CO
content:
If we had an official rulebook for our bike tour, number one would now be:

Don’t take route advice from anyone who hasn’t themselves ridden it on a fully-loaded road bike.

I should have listened to the little voice in my head that kept whispering ”follow the official route”. The allure of the to-good-to-be-true route that was more beautiful and had fewer cars was too great.

We had breakfast among the other guests in the communal kitchen, including Tyler who we’d met the day before, a young woman hiking the Continental Divide solo, and a very socially anxious man who hovered on the edge of the group, unsure what to do. We ate our yogurts, bananas and complimentary muffins with complimentary coffee, then loaded up and hit the road.

We took some nice back roads through Salida, past a golf course and some ultra-modern homes. It was all framed by beautiful mountains. People in Salida have it pretty good, I’d say.

Our plan was to stop at Mabel’s Deli in Poncha Springs for a Gatorade to jumpstart our hydration and conserve the water in our bottles. We ended up also getting tasty egg/cheese/avocado croissant sandwiches as we were still a bit peckish.

As we were leaving the deli and taking a left onto Route 285, I said to Tess, ”last chance to take Monarch Pass”. We continued on, however, five miles on a fairly busy road with a good shoulder to Marshall Pass Road.

The road was hard-packed dirt, and with almost no cars we were feeling good about our choice. We didn’t have service out here so I’d written down directions, and eventually we got to the junction with our first turnoff.

After a few hundred feet of rocky, high grade road, I I thought, ”was this the right turn”? I walked back down to check, and it wasn’t. Walked back up, grabbed the bike, headed back down. Good thing we weren’t taking that road, ha ha!

A little later we took the correct turn onto Route 200, which soon took us to our left onto 203. It was pitted and rocky, and maybe doable with suspension. I gritted my teeth and kept going, assuming this shit-path must end eventually. Confused campers looked on as we passed. Eventually after a mile or so I was swearing under my breath and uttering little things like ”completely ridiculous”, and ”this is stupid.” I heard a series of screams from behind me, which was Tess - I’d gone too far ahead and she got scared. She was in tears at this point, walking her bike to me. I delicately said, ”Tess, we’re not walking our bikes all the way up the mountain!”

I was ready to power ahead, when a Forest Service pickup truck started to pass us. A ways behind, he and Tess were talking out of earshot. Apparently, 203 only got more rugged, and we should instead go back to 200 and take it all the way up to Marshall Pass. The grade was lower and it was less rocky, but it would take longer. Incredibly, both his parents were from East Aurora!

Boy, was I pissed. I was picturing the smug faces of the guys who gave us these directions, and picturing smacking those faces. Route 200 was slightly better, but looser and with large gravel mixed in. Every so often the dirt would get loose without warning and our too-thin tires would sink in, and we’d have to quickly click out of the pedals as we skidded to a halt. Or we’d hit a big piece of gravel and our heavy-as-shit bikes would shoot sideways towards the edge of the road. At each of these instances, Tess would scream or moan. I was emitting low growls.

After a while I started getting used to it, enjoying the scenery and taking each patch of quicksand as it came. I was even smiling. Tess wasn’t feeling the same way - at one point she cried, ”just leave me behind!” It was 12 miles from the bottom of 200 to the pass, and after a long while I looked at our progress…9.8 to go. It was going to be a long day.

Then things took a turn for the worse. Apparently they’d just graded this section of road, and it became a mixture of beach sand and large rocks. Two feet, then our tires would sink in. One more foot, bike stopped. We’d wade across to the other side of the road, thinking it looked more solid, and after ten feet, it became sand. We’d hit a good patch, and then five dirt bikes would come through, forcing us to pull over. During the worst stretch, it took us an hour to go two miles. Whenever we took a second to stop and drink water, we would notice the scenery was pretty good. Mount Ouray loomed over us and we literally inched closer to it as we chugged along.

Then - miraculously - we crossed a threshold into a different county or jurisdiction and the dirt became hard-packed. Though we still had a good incline and big rocks, our speed doubled. I think if conditions hadn’t changed we wouldn’t have gotten to Sargents until after dark. We were incredibly thankful.

Finally, we hit a long straightaway that would bring us to Marshall Pass. We rounded a corner and a grand view opened up in front of us. How the hell we’d done it, we weren’t sure. We agreed we’d call the bike shop in Salida and discourage them from giving any other bike tourists similar advice. For the moment, we rejoiced and enjoyed a snack atop the Continental Divide.

A few other folks who’d gotten to the pass on a motorized vehicle of some sort were astounded we’d come up on Route 200, but assured us the downhill on the other side was super smooth. They also started telling us an alternate route for future days, and we nodded without listening. No more advice. Everyone’s an expert. Sticking to the route.

Guess what? The road down sucked. It was washed out, pitted, and really rocky. We had to go about as slow as we were going on the ascent, because every bump would throw us and our gear sky high. My flip-flop fell off the bike on two occasions (rescued both times). Our spines, arms and shoulders were getting absolutely wrecked. The descent got me into a fury. The usual trick to get me through tough moments (it will be a great story later!) wasn’t working. Shouts of anger the whole way down. The beauty of our surroundings was meaningless, as I didn’t see any of it. Focused completely on every rock, bump, and ditch. Completely unsuitable for a fully-loaded road bike.

So infuriated was I that it took me a good hour, a burger and a beer to simmer down after we arrived at Tomichi Creek Trading Post in Sargents, Colorado. We arrived at 4pm, with an original plan to arrive before noon. It was a damn good veggie burger I might add, slathered in pesto. Our waiter, Jesse, was overly nice which was just what I needed at that moment.

After sitting for a long time at dinner we got a campsite and set up our tent. We showered and sat in the dining room again drinking hot tea and writing our posts. When a man from a neighboring table asked if he could use our ketchup, Tess clutched it to her chest and jokingly said, ”no, we’re using it sorry!” He was surprised and said, ”OK,” and started looking around for a bottle on another table. She assured him it was just a joke, but he didn’t really get it.

Finally fully calmed down, we retired to our campsite and got cozy. It was getting really chilly. It had looked like a storm was going to break out all evening, but it never did. In the tent, we noted the miracles of the day:

  • We didn’t get seriously injured
  • We didn’t irreversibly damage our bikes
  • The weather was perfect

Feeling thankful, we fell asleep to the sounds of dirt bikers talking around crackling campfires.
